stream_context.summary: Kaze refactors remaining vanilla Mario 64 code out of the project, notes small but meaningful RAM savings, and iterates on an overworld setpiece: a “Pandora’s box” treasure chest that unleashes Boobla ghosts. The design conversation shifts from an initially vague “infestation” idea toward a clearer gameplay loop where Booblas become a traversal tool (launching Mario upward) to reach a star/cliff, with explicit warning text to prevent player confusion.
stream_context.significance_reason: Contains a concrete overworld mission concept (Pandora’s box → permanent ghost infestation + Boobla-as-traversal mechanic), plus meaningful engine refactoring decisions (removing level script/S-register concept and rewriting remaining vanilla code).

findings.summary: Kaze is systematically removing remaining vanilla Mario 64 code from RTYI by deleting any functions he didn’t write and reimplementing them in his own style, aiming to avoid shipping original vanilla implementations.
findings.quote: Every function I didn't write myself, I'm just backspacing it and reimplementing it in my own words.

findings.summary: As part of refactoring, the test stage now behaves differently: the prior “level script” approach (including the S-register/level script concept) has been removed entirely.
findings.quote: The whole concept of S register and level script is gone.

findings.summary: Kaze expects refactoring to yield small RAM wins (he mentions ~4KB as a typical benefit), and later notes a larger real save from a change (about ~12KB), though he’s not fully certain of the exact number.
He intentionally avoids null-pointer checks in some places; instead he forces a crash with an obvious marker so bugs can’t be missed during development.
findings.quote: I don't null pointer check. Instead, I just throw an arrow like that and crash the game. So that way, whenever something is wrong in my game, there's 0% chance to miss it.

findings.summary: He says they’re “almost done” with the first part of the first overworld and wants to run an end-to-end flow test of the first five courses to validate the gameplay formula/pacing.

Overworld setpiece plan: a later-reachable area will contain a chest (“Pandora’s box”); opening it unleashes Booblas. Kaze pivots from a simple “beat the infestation” concept to a more legible mechanic where Booblas launch Mario upward to access otherwise unreachable terrain/stars.

He considers making the Boobla infestation a permanent overworld state change (opening Pandora’s box can’t be undone), but worries players will assume they must “defeat” the ghosts; he proposes explicit warning text before opening the box to manage expectations.
findings.quote: This box contains great evil. Are you sure you want to open it? You cannot put back what you find inside.

findings.summary: Kaze decides to have Zeina create the Pandora’s box model; he’ll use a placeholder asset in the meantime.
findings.quote: I'm going to have Zeina make Pandora's box.

findings.summary: He reviews/iterates Boobla visuals and animation: the enemy should mostly appear as a blob, then periodically “pops out” (scaling/arm motion). He flags texture/UV resolution issues and considers switching parts to vertex colors to preserve quality.
Kaze describes a shift in sponsorship dynamics: instead of seeking sponsors after finishing a video, he now gets so many offers that sponsors arrive before a new video is ready.
findings.quote: I get an offer before I have a new video ready. So it's kind of the opposite way around.

findings.summary: He observes that titles strongly affect performance; a more sensational/negative framing improved results compared to a straightforward “perfecting” title, reinforcing that he feels pressured to be somewhat sensationalist.
findings.quote: Just another proof that you need to be somewhat sensationalist.

findings.summary: On playtesting feedback, Kaze emphasizes interpreting player emotion rather than implementing literal suggestions—players often misdiagnose what they want changed.
findings.quote: When you get feedback on your game you should never look at what they are actually saying. You should just look at what they are feeling.

findings.summary: He reiterates that he considers RTYI in its “final stages,” clarifying that remaining work is largely overworld construction and polish rather than core engine feasibility.
findings.quote: I'm in the final stages of making the game, which I am. I'm just making the overworld now.

zeina.summary: Kaze assigns Zeina the task of modeling Pandora’s box for the overworld, while he proceeds with a placeholder.
zeina.quote: I'm going to have Zeina make Pandora's box.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: When you get feedback on your game you should never look at what they are actually saying. You should just look at what they are feeling.
memorable_quotes.context: He explains his philosophy for handling playtester feedback—extracting the underlying emotional problem rather than implementing the proposed fix.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: This isn't a democracy. This is my sleepover and I get to pick the movie.
memorable_quotes.context: While reacting to chat requests and feature demands, he draws a clear boundary about creative control and decision-making.

key_stories.title: Designing Pandora’s box so the Boobla ‘infestation’ is fun and readable
key_stories.summary: Kaze wants an overworld moment where opening a chest unleashes Booblas, but realizes a vague ‘fight the infestation’ concept could be confusing—especially if the ghosts can’t be defeated. The stream captures him iterating toward a clearer loop: Booblas become a traversal mechanic that launches Mario upward, and the box is gated with warning text to set expectations.
key_stories.challenge: The initial idea (‘Pandora’s box releases Booblas; beat the infestation’) didn’t answer how the player wins or what Booblas are for, risking confusion and a ‘stupid feeling’ setpiece.
key_stories.process: He brainstorms options (permanent world change; warning prompt; chest with chains and multi-kick interaction; cutscene/particles; using Booblas to reach a star) and tests reachability/height so the star can’t be obtained without interacting with the mechanic.
key_stories.outcome: He converges on a platforming-focused solution: Booblas approach, move under Mario, and launch him upward to access an otherwise unreachable cliff/star; he keeps the Pandora’s box framing and plans explicit warning text.
key_stories.key_quote: Players are going to feel like they need to do something with the ghosts to get rid of them or something... So I fear that this is going to lead to confusion.

key_stories.title: Refactoring out remaining vanilla Mario 64 code (and deleting the level-script paradigm)
key_stories.summary: Kaze describes a deliberate effort to purge remaining vanilla implementations from the project by rewriting any functions he didn’t author. This refactor also changes foundational assumptions—his test stage no longer uses the old level-script/S-register model—signaling a maturing custom engine identity.
key_stories.challenge: Residual dependence on original vanilla source code and older control structures (level scripts/S-register) conflicts with his goal of a fully custom codebase and maintainability.
key_stories.process: He audits vanilla code, deletes/reimplements functions, and accepts disruptive changes (test stage behavior changes) as part of the cleanup; he uses aggressive crash-on-error tactics to catch issues immediately.
key_stories.outcome: He reports modest memory improvements (mentions ~4KB typical; later ~12KB saved from a change) and a clearer separation from vanilla Mario 64 architecture moving forward.
key_stories.key_quote: The whole concept of S register and level script is gone.

key_stories.title: Learning to ‘sell’ videos: title changes and the pull toward sensationalism
key_stories.summary: Kaze compares two titles for a recent video and notes a measurable performance difference. He frames it as another data point that creators are rewarded for more alarmist framing, even when the content is simply iterative development work.
key_stories.challenge: A video underperformed with a straightforward, positive title despite solid content.
key_stories.process: He changes the title from a ‘perfecting’ framing to a ‘must be reworked’ framing and watches the metrics improve.
key_stories.outcome: He concludes he has to be ‘somewhat sensationalist’ to compete for clicks, shaping how development gets communicated publicly.
key_stories.key_quote: Just another proof that you need to be somewhat sensationalist.

open_questions.topic: Pandora’s box: permanent overworld consequences and player communication
open_questions.context: Kaze likes the idea that opening Pandora’s box permanently changes the overworld (Booblas remain), but worries players will assume they must eliminate the ghosts. He proposes a warning prompt and shifts toward using Booblas as a traversal mechanic to make their role obvious.
questions: Do you still want Pandora’s box to be a permanent, irreversible overworld change—and what narrative/theme is that meant to express in RTYI?
How did you test whether players understood ‘Booblas are a tool’ (launch mechanic) rather than ‘enemies to clear’? What feedback would make you revert to a non-permanent infestation?
What does the final warning/cutscene look like, and how many interactions (kicks/steps) do you need before the box opens to ensure players feel responsible for the choice?

open_questions.topic: ‘Purging vanilla’: motivation and risk behind rewriting remaining Mario 64 code
open_questions.context: Kaze is deleting/reimplementing functions he didn’t write, aiming to avoid using vanilla implementations, and he’s already removed the level-script/S-register paradigm. He also notes porting a ‘new libultra’ as a remaining engine upgrade.
questions: Is the goal of rewriting vanilla code primarily legal/ethical clarity, technical ownership/maintainability, or performance—and which part mattered most to you emotionally as a creator?
What broke (or almost broke) when you removed level scripts/S-register, and what did that unlock architecturally for RTYI’s engine?
Where does the ‘new libultra’ port sit on the critical path now, and what capability does it enable that the current setup cannot?

open_questions.topic: Zeina’s Pandora’s box asset: art direction constraints in a freer camera overworld
open_questions.context: Kaze mentions Zeina’s prior ship texture worked best with a stiff camera angle, but the overworld camera changed; he then assigns Zeina the Pandora’s box model for this ghost area setpiece.
questions: What specific camera/art-style constraints made earlier overworld textures or models ‘not fit’ once the camera became freer—and what rules did you establish afterward for new overworld props?
What reference(s) are you using for Pandora’s box (Yoshi’s Island, original myth imagery, or an RTYI-specific visual language), and how do you want it to read from a distance?
How do you two divide iteration responsibilities—does Zeina deliver multiple variants, or do you block it out first and she polishes after gameplay is proven?
